alert_summary.description: Advisory is for January 28 (today) in nearby counties; not in effect for Thursday Jan 29. Main lingering concern for Jan 29 is leftover slick spots plus fog/ice risk rather than accumulating snow.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Thursday 2026-01-29 in Rockford, MI: temperatures stay well below freezing all day (low near 3°F, high near 15°F) with light winds. Snow accumulation is essentially zero and no plowable snowfall is expected, so a classic Michigan snow day is unlikely. The main school-impact risk is ice/visibility: a brief light freezing rain signal around midnight followed by freezing fog with periods of near-zero visibility (especially pre-dawn into early morning). Even tiny glaze/black-ice plus dense freezing fog can create hazardous bus and commute conditions despite minimal precip. If the freezing fog persists into the 6–9 AM window, a delay is more plausible than a full closure; otherwise, expect normal operations with slick/patchy icy spots.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Cold, quiet mid-winter day with little/no new snow (high pressure influence) and light winds: road crews can keep up easily and schools usually run on time unless there is a separate ice issue left over from the prior day.

Post-lake-effect setup: nuisance snow showers end, but lingering low visibility/fog patches around daybreak can create localized travel slowdowns (especially rural low spots) without meeting typical closure thresholds.

Trace freezing drizzle / light freezing rain overnight with temps in the single digits to teens: closures depend far more on glaze/black ice than snow totals; often results in delays rather than full closures if amounts are truly trace.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in West Michigan commonly features persistent cold, frequent lake-effect cloudiness/snow showers, and occasional arctic air shots. Schools in Michigan generally tolerate light/moderate snow well; closures usually require either (a) significant snow with bad timing (often ~8–10+ inches in/near the commute window), (b) widespread ice glazing, (c) true blizzard conditions/whiteouts, or (d) extreme wind chills near or below about -15°F (policy-dependent by district).
unusual_factors: The day itself shows near-zero precipitation/snow accumulation, which strongly lowers closure risk versus a typical lake-effect January day.
A key risk signal is visibility: multiple overnight/early-morning hours show very low visibility (0–1 mile, even 0 in the feed), consistent with fog/freezing fog potential and/or dense low stratus.
There is an hour flagged as 'Light freezing rain' around 12:00 AM with a trace amount; even tiny glaze on untreated surfaces can matter more than snow totals.
Temperatures remain well below freezing all day (roughly 3°F to 15°F), so any moisture/compaction from prior precipitation will not melt and can refreeze into slick spots.

local_microclimates: Rockford sits in the broader lake-effect-influenced region of West Michigan; conditions can vary sharply over a few miles, especially with lake-effect bands and fog/low stratus.
Rural/wooded and low-lying areas around Rockford can see thicker freezing fog and more persistent slick spots on less-traveled roads, even when main roads are fine.
infrastructure_considerations: West Michigan road commissions are typically well-equipped for snow; with no accumulating snow forecast on 01-29, plowing demand is low.
The bigger operational concern is early-morning spot treatment for black ice if freezing drizzle/fog deposits a thin glaze, especially on bridges/overpasses and shaded roads.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford’s modest elevation changes won’t drive mountain-style impacts, but small hills and shaded valleys can hold onto black ice longer, making localized slick travel more likely than widespread impassability.

history.confidence_assessment: Overall snow-day probability for Thursday 2026-01-29 appears low because snowfall accumulation is essentially zero and winds are light (no blizzard/whiteout signal). The main watch-outs are (1) a trace freezing drizzle/freezing rain around midnight and (2) very low visibility/freezing fog indications overnight into early morning. In Michigan, that combination more commonly produces isolated slick spots and occasional delays rather than a full closure—unless the fog/drizzle produces a meaningful glaze over a wide area or untreated roads remain hazardous from prior-day conditions. Confidence is medium because the highest-impact factor here (thin ice/visibility near daybreak) can be highly localized and sensitive to small temperature/dewpoint changes.

safety_recommendations: Primary operational concern is **black ice**: temperatures remain well below freezing all day (single digits to mid-teens °F), so any residual moisture/treated slush from prior events can refreeze, especially on bridges, shaded curves, and ramps.

A brief period of **light freezing rain around 12:00 AM** (very light QPF ~0.01 in) can glaze untreated surfaces before overnight plow/salt cycles fully catch up. Ensure overnight treatment on known slick spots.

Forecast shows **near-zero visibility (0 mi) from ~4:00–8:00 AM**, consistent with freezing fog/low stratus. This can create sudden “white wall” visibility drops on rural segments and at hill/valley transitions; buses should reduce speed and increase following distance.

Expect a “better on main roads, worse on neighborhood/rural roads” pattern: primary routes likely treated, but **secondary roads and subdivision streets** may stay slick/patchy because there’s little new precip to help abrasives bond and extremely cold pavement reduces salt effectiveness.

Use **delayed start considerations** (rather than full closure) if your district has many rural bus routes: pushing start 1–2 hours can allow fog/low vis to lift and for spot treatments to be verified at daylight.

Manage pedestrian risk: with wind chills near/just below 0°F around the commute, require winter gear and consider limiting long outdoor waits at bus stops; ensure sidewalks/entries are checked for refreeze.
Operational checks: run early-morning test drives on typical problem areas (bridges, low spots, by the river, shaded roads), and confirm parking lots/sidewalks are treated before arrival.

county_roads.estimated_clear_time: Improving through Wed afternoon/evening (2026-01-28) as crews scrape/push back; by Thu 6:30 AM (2026-01-29) most primaries/busier connectors should be passable, but slick/hard-pack spots can persist all morning in the cold.

local_streets.estimated_clear_time: Residential/local streets will lag behind primaries; expect continued slick/hard-pack areas early Thu (2026-01-29), with best improvement after sunrise and additional runs.

parking_lots.estimated_clear_time: School/municipal lots typically cleared later than roads; expect spotty conditions early Thu (2026-01-29) unless facilities crews pre-treat/clear overnight.

clearing_timeline.snow_end_time: Light snow/freezing precip tapers Wed (2026-01-28) with minimal additional precip shown Thu daytime; however, freezing fog late Thu night is a separate risk.
clearing_timeline.estimated_road_condition_at_6_30_am: For Thu 2026-01-29 at ~6:30 AM: major routes should be drivable, but expect hard-packed snow and isolated slick/icy patches—especially on hills/curves/intersections and less-traveled neighborhood roads. Biggest operational risk is low visibility from fog/freezing fog around the pre-dawn hours.

infrastructure.overall_clearing_assessment: Based on KCRC’s Wednesday 2026-01-28 6:45 AM operational update (scraping/pushing back snow; abrasives on hills/curves/stops/intersections; slick and hard-packed snow persisting due to extreme cold), and your Thu 2026-01-29 forecast showing little additional accumulation but potential fog/freezing fog, the most likely outcome is: NO full snow day for Rockford-area schools on Thu 2026-01-29, but a DELAY is plausible if early-morning fog/freezing fog materially reduces visibility on bus routes and if residual hard-pack remains widespread on neighborhood pickup roads.

Snow-day risk from power reliability alone is low; the bigger risk is cold-exposure and any early-morning slick spots/visibility issues from freezing fog/light icing.

Weather Underground page snippet is not aligned to the target date (it displays Jan 22, 2026 content in the crawl snippet), so it cannot be used to verify Thu 2026-01-29 feels-like precisely.

No verified source in the retrieved web snippets shows wind chill/feels-like below -20°F for Rockford, MI on Thu 2026-01-29. (However, several web sources retrieved are not reliably tied to the target date, so confidence is limited.)

webWeatherVerifier.verification_summary: Target date: Thu 2026-01-29 (Rockford, MI 49341). Your WeatherAPI forecast for Thu shows light winds (generally 2–6 mph) and a cold morning with a lowest hourly 'feels like' around -3.3°F (08:00) and generally between about -3°F to +6°F through the day, with essentially 0" snow. Web verification is inconclusive/conflicting with the snippets retrieved: (1) Weather.com (US unit page) shows morning feels-like around ~1–2°F with temps mid-to-upper teens, which is warmer than WeatherAPI by ~4–6°F on feels-like; (2) an alternate Weather.com locale page shows much colder feels-like values (down near -22°C to -24°C), which would be substantially colder than your API; (3) Weather Underground content in the crawl snippet appears to be for Jan 22, 2026, not Jan 29, so it can't verify the target day; (4) a regional local-news forecast mentions Thursday wind chills as low as about -11°F (region-wide), which does not breach -20°F but is not Rockford-specific. Because multiple retrieved public pages are clearly not synchronized to Thu 2026-01-29, I cannot confirm a precise cross-source consensus for that date from the current web snippets alone.

final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist synthesis:
1) Agreement: All experts converge on (a) essentially no accumulating snow, (b) no dangerous wind-chill trigger (not ≤ -20°F), (c) primary risk is fog/visibility + patchy black ice/refreeze, and (d) a delay is more plausible than a full closure.
2) Disagreement: The key conflict is how literally to take the WeatherAPI ‘0 mi visibility’ hours. Meteorology cautions it may be an encoding artifact; Safety treats it as a meaningful bus-safety red flag. Web verification could not confirm METAR/AFD, so I weight this as a real risk but with uncertainty.
3) Plow timing math: Measurable/impactful precip largely wrapped up by late Wed morning/early afternoon, leaving ~17 hours until 6:30 AM Thu for overnight touch-up. Infrastructure expects primaries/bus-route arterials passable by 6:30 AM, with neighborhoods lagging.
4) Ice: Yes, but mainly isolated black ice/refreeze and spot glazing (not a widespread ice storm). That supports delay/caution more than district-wide closure.
5) Neighboring districts: News intel found no confirmed Thu 1/29 closure/delay announcements tonight across nearby districts checked—so no +15–20% cascade bump.
6) Power: Consumers roll-up shows extremely low outages; no meaningful outage adjustment.
7) Wind chill verification: Web verifier finds no credible signal of wind chill ≤ -20°F; thus no cold-based near-automatic closure.
8) What would make this wrong: If dense freezing fog truly produces widespread near-zero visibility on rural routes at 6–8 AM OR if trace icing is more widespread than expected on neighborhood roads/bridges, the district could choose a proactive closure (tail risk). Conversely, if fog is patchy/lifts early, it will be a normal day (or at most increased caution).

Weighting per directive: Meteorology (25%) and Safety (25%) drive the outcome: no snow lowers closure sharply, but the commute-window visibility/black-ice risk keeps a non-trivial tail. History (15%) anchors low closure rates for “no new snow” patterns. News intel (15%) provides no closure-cascade confirmation (keeps probability from rising). Infrastructure (10%) indicates roads mostly passable by 6:30 with neighborhood slick spots (supports delay over closure). Power (5%) lowers outage concern. Web verifier (5%) removes extreme cold as a closure driver.

Final call: 20% probability of a full closure (snow day). Practical expectation is ‘open’ with an elevated chance of a 1–2 hour delay; however this output specifically estimates closure probability per request.

for_schools: Plan for ‘delay-likely, closure-possible’ operations: have a 1–2 hour delay decision ready if fog is dense on rural routes at 5:30–6:15 AM.
Run early route checks focused on river/low-lying areas, bridges/overpasses, shaded curves, and neighborhood pickup roads; treat known slick spots before 6:30 AM.
If opening on time, implement reduced bus speeds and larger following distances; consider holding buses if sudden white-wall fog is observed.
Ensure entrances, sidewalks, and parking lots are treated for refreeze; extreme cold means any melt/refreeze becomes slick quickly.
for_residents: Assume patchy black ice even if roads look dry; slow down on bridges, ramps, and shaded neighborhood streets.
If fog is present, use low beams and increase following distance; expect sudden visibility drops in low spots.
Bundle for bus stops (single digits/teens with subzero feels-like at times) and minimize outdoor wait time.
for_authorities: Prioritize spot treatment on bridges/overpasses, hills, curves, and intersections before 6:30 AM; abrasives may outperform salt in extreme cold.
Use variable message signs/social posts to highlight ‘dense fog + black ice’ risk for the morning commute.
If visibility collapses on key corridors, coordinate with schools on rapid delay/route adjustments.

positions.rationale: Meteorologically, Thursday (2026-01-29) is a cold, mostly dry day with light winds—conditions that rarely produce a full closure absent heavy new snow, major ice accretion, or extreme wind chills. The only plausible school-disruptor in the forecast is a narrow window of trace freezing precip around midnight plus freezing fog/very low visibility into the early morning commute. That pattern more commonly yields a *delay* (especially for rural bus routes) than a district-wide closure. I’m setting a low-but-not-zero closure probability at 12% to account for the possibility that freezing fog is dense and widespread at 6–8 AM *and/or* the trace icing is more impactful than modeled on untreated secondary roads.
keyFactors: No plowable snowfall signal on Thu 2026-01-29 (day total precip ~0.02 mm; totalsnow 0 cm; daily snow chance only 6%)—this alone usually keeps districts open.
Winds are light (max ~5–6 mph). No blowing/drifting or true whiteout mechanism.

Primary risk is *ice + visibility*, not snow: an isolated “light freezing rain” hour near 12:00 AM with trace QPF (~0.01 in) plus multiple hours of forecast vis dropping to 0–1 mile pre-dawn (roughly 3–9 AM) consistent with freezing fog/low stratus.
Temps stay well below freezing all day (high ~15°F, low ~3°F), so any residual moisture/hard-pack from Wed will not melt and can remain slick for the morning bus window.

NWS Winter Weather Advisory in the payload is for Wed 2026-01-28 and different counties; no active Thu advisory shown here—suggests impacts are more localized/conditional rather than a broad, high-end event.

positions.rationale: History-based baseline: a cold, mostly dry day in late January in West Michigan is typically a normal school day (low closure base rate). I’m lifting the baseline slightly because the forecast contains two classic “non-snow” closure triggers: (1) a trace freezing-precip signal near midnight that can produce black ice, and (2) a notable pre-dawn visibility collapse consistent with freezing fog/low stratus, which can make rural bus routes unsafe even when main roads are passable. Still, without meaningful accumulation, high winds, or a strong/extensive ice signal, a *full* snow day remains unlikely; a delay is the more historically common outcome. Net: ~12% chance of a snow day (closure), with a higher implied chance of delay than closure.
keyFactors: Climatology/ops history for West Michigan in late January: districts are acclimated to cold and light snow; with **0" forecast snow** and **light winds**, full closures are historically uncommon.

The most “snow-day-relevant” historical analog here is **trace ice** (freezing drizzle/freezing rain around ~12:00 AM). Trace events more often yield **delays** or heightened caution than district-wide closures—unless glazing becomes widespread (not indicated by the tiny QPF).

**Freezing fog / very low visibility** signals (0–1 mi, even 0 mi) clustered pre-dawn into early morning can create localized bus-route hazards. Historically this raises delay odds more than closure odds, but it’s the main pathway to a closure on an otherwise quiet weather day.

**Residual impacts from prior day**: today (Wed 2026-01-28) has active winter weather messaging in nearby counties and reports of slick/packed roads regionally; with temps staying below freezing, “yesterday’s mess” can persist into Thursday morning, but tends to be mitigated by overnight/early scraping and treatment on primaries.
Derived from primary analysis

positions.rationale: From a news/operations standpoint, closures usually correlate with either (a) an announced forecast-driven expectation (major snow/ice storm headlines), (b) widespread active warnings/closures cascading across neighboring districts the night before, or (c) an obvious infrastructure failure (power/transport). For Thu 2026-01-29 in Rockford, none of those “headline” signals are present. However, the forecast’s near-zero visibility indications between roughly 4 AM–9 AM, plus trace icing, can disproportionately affect bus-route safety even without measurable snow—this is the main reason I’m not near 0%. Net: low chance of full closure, modest chance of a delay; I translate that into ~12% for an outright snow day/closure.
keyFactors: No credible signal of plowable snowfall on Thu 2026-01-29 (totals essentially 0"), so the classic “snow day” trigger is absent.

The only meaningful operational risk is **ice/visibility**: a trace “light freezing rain” signal around 12:00 AM plus multiple hours flagged with **very low/zero visibility** (freezing fog/low stratus) near the pre-dawn/early commute window.

No strong **district-communications** signal: Rockford Public Schools’ 1/27/26 update emphasizes their early-morning road-check process but does not pre-announce closure for Thu; neighboring districts’ earlier closures (Tue 1/27 and Fri 1/23) show a rough pattern of impactful weather this week, but don’t specifically imply a Thu closure.
Community/road chatter (Grand Rapids area) reads “mostly plowed but still slick in spots” rather than widespread impassability; that tends to align more with “monitor / maybe delay” than “close.”
Power-grid signal looks weak for closure: outages appear low overall; extreme cold adds stress but isn’t paired with wind/ice loading sufficient to expect widespread outages.

debates.topic: Your writeup treats 0-mile visibility from ~4–8 AM as a strong ‘significant commute impact.’ From a meteorology standpoint, the vis field here may be an artifact of how the feed encodes low stratus/fog; I’d like you to weight ‘0 mi’ less literally unless corroborated by METAR-style obs/trends. If it truly is dense freezing fog, then yes—delay risk rises, but closure still usually needs widespread persistence into/through the bus window.

For forecasting a Thu 2026-01-29 closure, I’d treat those as weak priors unless there’s confirmation of lingering untreated secondary roads or a fresh advisory/statement for Thu morning.

debates.topic: The hourly feed showing repeated **0-mile visibility** looks extreme; it may reflect model/parameterization artifacts (or sensor/encoding quirks) rather than a guaranteed dense freezing fog outcome. If that value is overstated, closure probability should drop; if it’s real and widespread at 6–8 AM, probability should rise (especially for delays). Consider bracketing scenarios around realistic vis thresholds (e.g., 0–0.25 mi vs 0.5–1 mi).

debates.topic: Safety leans toward ‘significant’ morning commute impact. That’s plausible, but I’d want explicit differentiation between **delay-likely** vs **full-closure** triggers. With minimal precip and light winds, many districts still run (sometimes with a 2-hr delay) unless there’s confirmed widespread glazing or crash spikes.

positions.rationale: I’m keeping the closure probability **low overall** because there’s no accumulating snow and no wind/blizzard component, which are the usual triggers for a district-wide closure in West Michigan. However, I’m **raising my prior 12% up to 18%** because the forecast repeatedly flags near-zero visibility overnight into the morning commute and includes a small freezing-rain/drizzle signal around midnight. Dense freezing fog plus patchy black ice can create a “widespread enough” bus-safety problem even when totals are near zero—still more likely to produce a **delay** than a full closure, but the closure tail risk is non-trivial if fog is widespread at 6–8 AM and road temps are extremely cold.
keyFactors: No plowable snowfall expected Thu 2026-01-29 (totalsnow_cm = 0; daily snow chance only 6%) and winds are light (max ~5–6 mph) → classic snow-day drivers absent.

Primary meteorological risk is **ice + visibility**, not snow: an hourly “light freezing rain” signal near 12:00 AM with trace QPF (~0.01 mm/in equivalent) can create patchy glaze/black ice on untreated surfaces.

Multiple hours indicate **freezing fog / very low visibility** (several hours show 0–1 mile, even 0) in the pre-dawn through early morning window; that’s the one factor that can force operational decisions for buses even with minimal precip.

Temperatures stay well below freezing all day (low ~3°F, high ~15°F). Any moisture from Wed’s lake-effect / freezing precip won’t melt and can refreeze/compact → lingering slick spots into the Thu AM commute.
Light winds mean no blowing/drifting snow, and also suggest fog could linger in valleys/low spots (less mixing), but the areal coverage may be localized—key uncertainty.

positions.rationale: From a history-of-operations perspective, Thursday 2026-01-29 looks like a classic “no new snow” day where districts in West Michigan typically stay open. That anchors the probability low (single digits). I’m raising it into the low-teens because the forecast includes two higher-leverage historical drivers of disruptions without snowfall: a brief freezing-precip signal near midnight and a pronounced pre-dawn visibility collapse that overlaps the 6–9 AM decision window. Even so, the most common historical outcome for this pattern is a delayed start rather than a full closure, so I’m not moving toward the Safety agent’s higher closure probability.
keyFactors: Historical baseline in West Michigan: late-January cold + little/no new snowfall + light winds is usually a normal school day (closures are uncommon without plowable snow, widespread ice accretion, or true blizzard/whiteout).

Non-snow closure triggers are present: (a) trace light freezing rain signal around 12:00 AM Thu 2026-01-29, and (b) multiple pre-dawn hours showing extremely low visibility (0–1 mile, even 0 in the feed) consistent with freezing fog/low stratus—this combination can create bus-route safety concerns despite minimal precipitation.

Persistence of subfreezing temps all day (roughly 3°F to 15°F) means any leftover moisture/hard-pack from Wed (2026-01-28) won’t melt; historically, that raises the odds of patchy black ice on secondary roads and rural pickups.

Local context signals recent impactful weather earlier in the week (e.g., neighboring-district closures on Tue 2026-01-27), which can leave residual road issues that sometimes tip a marginal fog/ice morning into a closure decision—though more often it produces a delay.

positions.rationale:
As the safety specialist, I’m weighting the *operational risk during the bus/parent commute window* more than storm totals. The forecast suggests a short overnight freezing-precip window and then a prolonged period of potentially dense freezing fog/low visibility into the morning commute on Thu 2026-01-29. That combination can produce high crash risk even without new snow, particularly on rural/secondary segments and at typical trouble spots (bridges, shaded curves, stop-controlled hills). 

However, the precip amounts are trace, winds are light, and districts in West Michigan typically do not close for cold alone at these wind chills. This pushes me away from my prior 40% and toward a lower number, closer to the meteorology/history/news cluster—while still staying *above* them because “0 mi visibility” (if it verifies) is a bus-safety red flag that can force a closure even when totals are low. Net: I land at **22%** for a full snow day/closure (with a meaningfully higher chance of a **delay** than closure).
keyFactors: No plowable snow is forecast on Thu 2026-01-29 (0" snow; essentially no accumulation), which strongly suppresses full-closure odds.

Primary safety driver is **ice + visibility**, not snow: a trace **light freezing rain** signal around 12:00 AM plus temps staying in the single digits/teens all day means *any* moisture becomes persistent slick spots (bridges, intersections, shaded/rural segments).

Multiple hours show **very low/near-zero visibility** (esp. ~04:00–09:00). Even if roads are passable, dense freezing fog can make bus operations unsafe—this is the most “closure-like” risk in the dataset.

Road-condition asymmetry: primaries likely okay (treated), but **secondary/neighborhood roads** (where buses actually collect students) can remain patchy/hard-pack/black-ice, especially in extreme cold where salt effectiveness drops.
Wind is light (no blowing snow), and there’s no active Thu advisory for the Rockford area in the payload—both reduce the likelihood of a systemwide shutdown.

positions.rationale: As the NEWS/operations lens, I weight (1) explicit district communications, (2) whether a regional ‘closure cascade’ is already forming the evening before, and (3) whether there’s a clear headline driver (major storm warning, mass outages, impassable roads). For Thu 2026-01-29, Rockford Public Schools has not posted a specific closure/delay decision in the material surfaced, and neighboring-district closures cited are earlier-in-week rather than a fresh Thu-morning wave. Meteorologically, there’s little/no accumulating snow and light wind, which typically reduces the likelihood of a full closure. The main legitimate disruption vector is early-morning freezing fog/near-zero visibility plus trace icing on untreated surfaces, which can force transportation-driven decisions even absent snow. Balancing the weak ‘public signal’ for a closure against the non-trivial bus-safety hazard window, I’m slightly higher than the 12% camp but well below the 40% safety position: **18% chance of a full snow day (closure)** (with a higher, separate probability of a delay).
keyFactors: No district-level closure signal yet: Rockford Public Schools’ most recent superintendent update (dated Tue 2026-01-27) reiterates the morning road-check process but does not preview or announce a Thu 2026-01-29 closure.

Neighbor precedent is not aligned to Thu: nearby districts had closures earlier in the week (e.g., Tue 2026-01-27; Fri 2026-01-23), which shows the region has been impacted recently, but it’s not a direct ‘tomorrow’ cascade signal for Thursday.

Forecast impact is operational rather than headline: essentially no plowable snow and light winds, but a narrow overnight freezing-precip signal plus freezing fog/very low visibility risk in the pre-dawn to early-morning window (roughly 4–9 AM) can still trigger a *delay* or, less commonly, a closure if widespread and persistent on bus routes.

Residual-condition risk: community reports (Wed 2026-01-28) suggest main roads improving but ongoing slick/packed spots; combined with single-digit temps, refreeze/black ice could stay problematic on secondary roads.
No strong outage-driven closure catalyst identified: current grid/outage indicators don’t suggest widespread power loss that would push a closure decision.

Meteorologically, with very light QPF and low winds, the hazard can be **high-impact but localized**; I’d want evidence that freezing fog coverage is broad (not patchy) and persists into the bus window before going that high.

keyDisagreements.topic: Your writeup treats 0-mile visibility from ~4–8 AM as a strong ‘significant commute impact.’ From a meteorology standpoint, the vis field here may be an artifact of how the feed encodes low stratus/fog; I’d like you to weight ‘0 mi’ less literally unless corroborated by METAR-style obs/trends. If it truly is dense freezing fog, then yes—delay risk rises, but closure still usually needs widespread persistence into/through the bus window.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 28 at 3:45AM EST until January 28 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations up to one inch.

* WHERE...Allegan, Ottawa, and Van Buren Counties.

* WHEN...Until 10 AM EST this morning.

* IMPACTS...Roads will likely be slick and hazardous. Visibility and
road conditions may change rapidly over short distances in lake
effect snow. The hazardous conditions will impact the Wednesday
morning commute.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The combination of ongoing lake effect snow,
which we expect to increase in intensity during the morning
commute, as well as cold temperatures will result in slick travel
conditions.
alert.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 27 at 4:05PM EST until January 28 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to
an ice jam.


* WHERE...A portion of west central Michigan, including the
following county, Newaygo.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...Ice jams are notoriously unpredictable. Low-lying areas
along the Muskegon River that are prone to flooding may see
rapidly changing water levels as ice shifts and adjusts.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 318 PM EST, An ice jam was reported by local authorities
on the Muskegon river in southern Newaygo County. The river
gauge at Newaygo shows water levels remaining at minor flood
stage as of Tuesday afternoon.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. While
flooding associated with freeze up ice jams is typically
minor, conditions can change rapidly and unpredictably.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Newaygo.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
alert.instruction:
Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement and request they pass this information to the National
Weather Service when you can do so safely.
